quiz.title: Algebra 2: Unit 10 Quiz 4
quiz.subtitle: 10.4: Sampling Methods and Bias
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Evaluating methods for collecting data and recognizing sources of error

questions.question: A researcher wants to study the sleeping habits of high school students. They assign every student a number and use a random number generator to select 50 students. Which sampling method is being used?
questions.explanation: A Simple Random Sample (SRS) gives every member of the population and every possible group of size $n$ an equal chance of being selected.

questions.question: A company wants to know how employees feel about a new benefit. They interview every employee in the Sales and Marketing departments. Which sampling method is this?
questions.explanation: Cluster sampling involves dividing the population into groups (clusters) and then selecting entire clusters to interview.

questions.question: To determine the popularity of a new \$5 meal deal, a fast-food manager surveys the first 20 customers who enter the restaurant. Why is this sample biased?
options: It is a convenience sample and not representative of all customers
The sample size is too large
The question is a leading question
questions.explanation: Convenience sampling is biased because it only includes people who are easy to reach, failing to represent the entire population's diversity.

questions.question: A principal wants to ensure that students from all four grade levels are represented in a survey. She randomly selects 25 students from each grade. Which sampling method is this?
questions.explanation: Stratified sampling divides the population into groups (strata) based on a characteristic (grade level) and then samples from each group.

questions.question: A news station asks viewers to visit their website and vote on a controversial new tax that will cost homeowners \$200 per year. What is the primary source of bias in this poll?
questions.explanation: Voluntary response samples are biased because people with strong (usually negative) opinions are the most likely to participate.

questions.question: A quality control inspector selects every $15^{th}$ lightbulb off the assembly line to test for defects. Which sampling method is being used?
questions.explanation: Systematic sampling follows a fixed interval or rule, such as selecting every $n^{th}$ individual.

questions.question: A survey asks: 'Given that the current \$1,500 property tax is already a burden, do you support a further increase to fund the park?' This is an example of:
questions.explanation: Leading questions use suggestive wording to influence the respondent's answer toward a specific conclusion.

questions.question: Which of the following would most likely reduce bias in a study?
options: Increasing the sample size without changing the method
Asking only people you know personally
Allowing participants to opt-in via social media
questions.explanation: Randomization is the most effective way to eliminate bias and ensure the sample is representative of the population.

questions.question: A pollster calls 500 households, but only 50 people answer the phone and complete the survey. What type of bias is most prevalent here?
questions.explanation: Non-response bias occurs when a significant portion of the sampled population cannot be reached or refuses to participate.

questions.question: A surveyor at the mall wants to know how much people spend on clothes. He only surveys teenagers. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: Undercoverage occurs when some members of the population (in this case, adults or children) are left out of the process of choosing the sample.

scoreMessages.90: Great eye for identifying bias and sampling techniques!
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Review the difference between 'Stratified' and 'Cluster' sampling.
scoreMessages.50: Remember: Randomness is key to a good sample!
scoreMessages.0: Sampling is about representation. Think about who is being left out of the group.
